summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the case against Ghislaine Maxwell. The government requests limited redactions to protect the privacy of third parties mentioned in defense filings related to a proposed Rule 17(c) subpoena, specifically in documents involving the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner LLP.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell; recipient of this government letter regarding redaction requests.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330) which is the subject of this government filing.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who respectfully submits this letter to the court.

events.title: Court Order on Redaction Requests
events.description: The Court issued an order directing the Government to submit any requests for redaction of information contained in filings regarding the defense's proposed Rule 17(c) subpoena.

events.title: Joint Letter on Redactions
events.description: A joint letter was filed addressing redactions to documents related to the defense's proposed Rule 17(c) subpoena and objections from Boies Schiller Flexner LLP.

locations: One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The government is seeking to redact names and identifying information of third parties from defense filings to protect their privacy.
The redaction request pertains specifically to documents involving the defense's proposed Rule 17(c) subpoena and objections from the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner LLP (BSF).
The government asserts the proposed redactions are narrowly tailored and consistent with legal precedent (Lugosch v. Pyramid Co.).
Both defense counsel and counsel from BSF indicated they take no position on the government's redaction requests.
The document is part of the ongoing criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell (20 Cr. 330).
